subject: And now for something completely different: The Way of Testivus
msgSnippet: A while back - just for fun - I took a pretty bad pun on Seinfeld s Festivus a bit too far and blogged about Testivus - Unit testing for the rest of us :
messageBody:
A while back - just for fun - I took a pretty bad pun on Seinfeld's
"Festivus" a bit too far and blogged about "Testivus - Unit testing
for the rest of us":

http://www.artima.com/weblogs/viewpost.jsp?thread=194506

Based on the number of replies and positive emails I received from
that blog, I realized that the idea of Testivus (an approach to
unit/developer testing less focused on testing dogma and more on
testing karma) had struck a nerve and decided to take the idea of
Testivus even further and wrote "The Way of Testivus".

Since the inspiration for some of the ideas presented in TWOT came
from this and a couple of other groups, I thought I'd share it with
you. You might even recognize some of the text and arguments as
*near* plagiarism of some of the posts that have been made here.

In one case, in a tenet about what constitutes a unit test, I plucked
(no pun intended) a few sentences from Michael Feathers because I
could not possibly improve on them, but I gave him credit (albeit a
bit disguised).

You can find a fun, exotic, and "antiqued" looking PDF copy of "The
Way of Testivus" - complete with a background story on its mysterious
origins - at the following link:

http://www.agitar.com/downloads/TheWayOfTestivus.pdf

You can also read the basic tenets of Testivus on Wikpedia, but it's
not as cool looking or easy to read as the PDF.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Testivus

What do you think? What other tenets should we add to Testivus? Feel
free to suggest some.

Alberto
